properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and freezing rain is expected Wednesday. Snow with risk of freezing rain is expected to develop Wednesday morning and continue into Wednesday evening. The precipitation may also change over to rain Wednesday afternoon. Several hours of freezing rain are possible. Total snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 cm are also expected. Hazardous winter travelling conditions are expected, and motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T19:33:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T03:34:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1926189267.2019
Area: South River - Burk's Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long duration rainfall continues. Total rainfall amounts: 25 to 45 mm. Location: Cartwright to Lodge Bay. Time span: continuing until noon Wednesday. Remarks: While rainfall rates are not forecast to be heavy, significant amounts are still expected due to the long duration. Those travelling between communities should be on the lookout for localized flooding, minor washouts from runoff, and water pooling, especially in areas with higher existing snowpack. Some areas further inland and over higher elevations may also experience accumulating wet snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-27T16:59:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T01:46:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3623785646.2019
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain and some accumulating snow possible for Thursday. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm, mainly inland and over higher terrain. Locations: most of mainland Nova Scotia. Time span: late Wednesday night through Thursday evening. Remarks: Rain is expected to begin late Wednesday night and persist for much of the day Thursday, but likely will mix with or change to snow over inland areas and especially over higher terrain Thursday morning. Precipitation will gradually end Thursday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T17:56:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T01:57:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3273803889.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow possible Thursday. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Locations: southern New Brunswick Time span: late Wednesday night into Thursday afternoon. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin late Wednesday night and continue into Thursday afternoon. Snow could become mixed with rain later Thursday morning and into the afternoon, which could reduce snowfall accumulations in some areas. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are generally expected but could reach near 15 cm over higher terrain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T17:56:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T01:57:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1221356286.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow on the way for Thursday, except rain along Fundy coast. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Locations: southern New Brunswick Time span: late Wednesday night into Thursday afternoon. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin late Wednesday night and continue into Thursday afternoon when it will change to rain. The greatest snowfall accumulations are expected over the areas between St. Stephen and Sussex. General snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are likely with a possibility of up to 15 cm over higher terrain. Rain will prevail along the Fundy coast with amounts of 20 to 40 mm expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T00:12:52-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A variety of wintry weather and strong winds are expected. Time span: Friday through Saturday. Locations: across Newfoundland as outlined below. For eastern Newfoundland: A snow/rain mix is expected to begin Friday morning and change to all rain by Friday evening. Periods of rain will then persist through Saturday. Significant rainfall amounts are likely and warnings may be required. For central and northeastern Newfoundland: A snow/rain mix will begin around midday on Friday and persist through Saturday. Significant snowfall amounts are likely inland with rain along the coast and warnings may be required. Winds will also be strong especially along the coast. For western Newfoundland: Periods of snow will begin Friday afternoon or evening and then persist through Saturday. Strong northerly winds will accompany the snow Friday night into Saturday, resulting in the potential for reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Warnings may be required. Remarks: It is too early to forecast precipitation amounts for specific areas. Anyone planning travel should prepare for winter driving conditions. Alerts and forecasts issued by Environment and Climate Change Canada will be updated as more information becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-28T00:54:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T08:55:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0983917121.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected today. A rain and wet snow mix has moved in from Michigan as expected. The precipitation will change over to snow, heavy at times, this morning. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are likely by this evening. Hazardous winter driving conditions from very low visibility in snow and local blowing snow in exposed areas are expected today. Motorists should alter travel plans accordingly. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T02:14:44-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Southerly winds gusting to 80 km/h will continue to give blizzard conditions over Paulatuk early this morning. These winds are expected to diminish late this morning and allow the blizzard to end by early this afternoon. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T19:59:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T11:16:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3895013210.2019
Area: Paulatuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. After a brief period of snow or patchy freezing rain early this morning, precipitation will change over to plain rain. The rain will taper off to scattered showers and flurries by this evening. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 30 mm are expected by this evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T23:59:14-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain is expected to develop this morning and may persist for a couple of hours before changing over to a cold rain as temperatures edge just above the zero degree mark. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain today. A band of freezing rain is expected to develop across the region early this morning and may persist into the afternoon before changing over to rain or wet snow. Snowfall amounts will range from 2 centimetres or less near Burks Falls to near 10 cm over higher elevations in Algonquin Park and near the Quebec border. Hazardous winter travelling conditions are expected. Motorists should allow for extra time to reach their destination. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southwesterly wind with gusts near 90 km/h tonight. Very strong southwesterly winds with gusts near 90 km/h are expected to develop early this evening as a sharp cold front blasts through. These damaging winds will persist into the overnight hours before before veering to the west and diminishing. The highest wind gusts will be along exposed areas of the Lake Ontario shoreline. Power outages are possible. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T02:44:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T10:45:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0408312798.2019
Area: Picton - Sandbanks Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A winter storm with heavy snow and blowing snow is expected today. Snow is expected to move in from the south this morning and continue into this evening. Northeasterly winds gusting to 60 km/h will also produce blowing snow in exposed areas. Snowfall amounts near 15 cm are likely in the Wawa area and in regions near Lake Superior. Lesser snow amounts, perhaps near 5 cm are expected in areas northwest of White River which will be on the northern edge of this winter storm. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T02:11:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T10:12:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3515607970.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southwesterly winds with gusts to 80 km/h this evening. Strong southwesterly winds gusting to 80 km/h are expected to develop early evening in the wake of a sharp cold front blasting through Eastern Ontario. The strongest wind gusts will be along exposed areas of the Lake Ontario shoreline where there is a possibility of wind gusts approaching 90 km/h in one or two localities. Winds will veer to the west and ease after midnight tonight. Strong winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Isolated power outages are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T00:29:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T08:30:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2095377758.2019

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A prolonged period of snow is forecast for southwestern Alberta. Total snowfall amounts will be from 25 to 40 cm with some localities possibly exceeding 50 cm. Additionally, moderate to strong gusty northerly winds will develop today producing near zero visibilities in blowing snow. The snowfall is expected to end on Thursday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southwesterly winds gusting to 100 km/h this afternoon and evening. Very strong southwesterly winds gusting to 100 km/h will suddenly develop early this afternoon as a sharp cold front blasts through. These damaging winds will persist into this evening before veering to the west and diminishing. The highest wind gusts will be in exposed areas along the Lake Erie shore. Power outages are possible. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T02:43:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T10:44:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1214705145.2019
Area: Simcoe - Delhi - Norfolk, Dunnville - Caledonia - Haldimand, Niagara Falls - Welland - Southern Niagara Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A prolonged period of snow is forecast for southwestern Alberta starting tonight and continuing into Thursday. Total snowfall amounts will be from 20 to 30 cm with some localities possibly exceeding 50 cm. Additionally, moderate to strong gusty northerly winds will develop on Wednesday producing locally poor visibilities in blowing snow. As the system continues to develop, additional warnings may be the added, most likely in the Lethbridge, Vulcan and Calgary regions. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T20:45:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T04:46:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2956783170.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong southwesterly winds gusting to 80 km/h this afternoon. A sharp cold front blasting through Southwestern Ontario will cause the southeasterly winds to shift into the southwest by early afternoon, with frequent gusts of 70 to 80 km/h expected. The strong southwesterly winds will veer into the west and ease this evening. Strong winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Isolated power outages are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T00:13:09-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm with heavy snow and blowing snow today. Snow, heavy at times, is expected to move in from the south this morning then continue into this evening. Northeasterly winds gusting to 70 km/h will also produce blowing snow especially in exposed areas where local white out conditions are possible. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are likely by midnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T01:15:01-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant snowfall is expected today. Snow is expected to develop this morning and continue into this evening. The snow may be mixed with or change to rain over areas near and south of Lake Nipissing. Brief freezing rain is also possible. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are likely north of Lake Nipissing, particularly from Temiscaming to Marten River Provincial Park. North Bay will receive 10 to 15 cm of snow, with significantly lesser snow amounts of 2 to 5 cm for areas just to the south of Lake Nipissing where more rain is expected. North Bay will be very close to the rain-snow boundary. A slight change in the exact location of this boundary will affect how much snow will fall at that location. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T03:20:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-27T11:21:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1923950232.2019
Area: West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong southwesterly winds beginning this afternoon. Strong southwesterly winds gusting to 80 km/h are expected to develop this afternoon in the wake of a sharp cold front blasting across the region. Wind gusts may approach 90 km/h this afternoon especially in exposed areas. Winds will veer to the west and slowly ease this evening. Strong winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. A few power outages are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
